Name: Directive 2005/29/EC (Unfair Commercial Practices Directive - UCPD)
Key Provisions: Articles 5-9 (general prohibition, misleading actions/omissions, aggressive practices); Annex I (blacklist)
Relevance: Core instrument prohibiting misleading omissions (Art. 7) - applies when trader omits material information needed for informed transactional decision

Name: Directive 93/13/EEC (Unfair Terms in Consumer Contracts Directive - UCTD)
Key Provisions: Articles 3-5 (unfairness test, transparency requirement, plain intelligible language); Art. 4(2) (core terms exemption)
Relevance: Requires contractual terms in plain intelligible language (Art. 5); unfair if contrary to good faith and causes significant imbalance (Art. 3)

Name: Directive 2011/83/EU (Consumer Rights Directive - CRD)
Key Provisions: Articles 5-8 (pre-contractual information requirements for on/off-premises and distance contracts)
Relevance: Mandates specific pre-contractual information disclosure including main characteristics, price, duration of contract for continuous services

Name: Directive 98/6/EC (Price Indication Directive - PID)
Key Provisions: Article 6a (prior price indication for price reductions, as amended by Dir. 2019/2161)
Relevance: Requires clear, unambiguous price indication; relevant to pricing transparency in service offerings

Name: Directive 2019/770/EU (Digital Content Directive - DCD)
Key Provisions: Articles 6-10 (conformity requirements - subjective and objective); Article 8 (functionality, interoperability)
Relevance: Establishes conformity standards for digital services including functionality, quality expectations; trader liability for defects

Name: Directive 2019/2161/EU (Modernisation/Omnibus Directive)
Key Provisions: Amendments to UCPD, UCTD, CRD, PID - enhanced transparency, enforcement, penalties
Relevance: Modernizes consumer law for digital age; strengthens information duties and enforcement mechanisms

Name: Regulation 2019/1150/EU (Platform-to-Business Regulation - P2B)
Key Provisions: Article 3 (T&Cs transparency); Article 5 (ranking transparency); Article 4 (notice of changes)
Relevance: Platform transparency obligations; while B2B focused, illustrates EU transparency standards for online services

Name: Case C-26/13 Kásler and Káslerné Rábai (2014)
Key Provisions: Transparency requires contract terms set out mechanism allowing consumer to evaluate economic consequences; foreign currency loan terms must be comprehensible
Relevance: Establishes that transparency means consumer can assess practical effects; vague mechanisms violate transparency requirement

Name: Case C-92/11 RWE Vertrieb (2013)
Key Provisions: Unilateral price variation clauses must meet transparency, balance, good faith requirements; consumer must understand reason and mode of change
Relevance: Directly relevant to vague service terms; right to terminate insufficient if variation terms unclear; must specify reason/method of changes

Name: Case C-191/15 VKI v Amazon (2016)
Key Provisions: Standard terms choosing supplier's law unfair; applies consumer protection of Member State where consumer resides/is targeted
Relevance: Establishes principles for online service providers; fairness assessment applies to all standard terms in consumer contracts

Name: Case C-395/21, C-335/21 (D V transparency) (2022-2023)
Key Provisions: Transparency requires information sufficient for consumer to assess economic consequences; non-transparent core terms subject to unfairness review
Relevance: Recent jurisprudence on transparency of pricing/remuneration terms; vague hourly rate mechanisms violate transparency

Name: Case C-472/23 Lexitor (2025)
Key Provisions: Credit agreements must transparently specify APRC calculation, reason/method of fee variations; consumers must understand if circumstances arose and effects
Relevance: Most recent ruling emphasizing detailed transparency obligations; listing circumstances insufficient without clear explanation of effects

Name: Case C-646/22 Compass Banca (2024)
Key Provisions: Average consumer is reasonably well-informed, observant, circumspect; cognitive biases relevant to assessing commercial practice effects
Relevance: Clarifies 'average consumer' benchmark for assessing whether practice/omission materially distorts transactional decisions

Name: Case C-39/24 (Caixabank/BBVA arrangement fees) (2025)
Key Provisions: Transparency requires consumer assess financial consequences; merely stating fee amount insufficient without specifying services/performance time
Relevance: Recent consolidation: arrangement fees must specify what services provided in exchange; vague fee descriptions violate transparency

Name: EC Guidance on Consumer Rights Directive (DG Justice)
Key Provisions: Official guidance on interpretation and application of Directive 2011/83/EU provisions including information requirements
Relevance: Authoritative interpretation of pre-contractual information duties for on-premises, distance, off-premises contracts

Name: EC Notice on Price Indication Directive Article 6a (2021)
Key Provisions: Commission guidance on interpretation of prior price indication requirements, interaction with UCPD
Relevance: Clarifies price transparency obligations including scope, misleading price reduction announcements

Name: EC Guidelines on Ranking Transparency (P2B Regulation) (2020)
Key Provisions: Guidelines on Article 5 P2B Regulation: main parameters determining ranking, communication to businesses
Relevance: Illustrates EU approach to algorithmic/operational transparency in online service context

Name: Wiewiórowska-Domagalska (2024) 'Lost in Information: Transparency Dogma of UCTD' ERPL 32(1)
Key Provisions: CJEU shifted UCTD from content control to information-based protection; transparency requirement expanded beyond plain language to substantive comprehensibility
Relevance: Critical analysis of CJEU's transparency jurisprudence; documents evolution toward requiring terms enable consumer to assess practical consequences

Name: Junuzović (2018) 'Transparency of Pre-Contractual Information in Consumer Credit' CYELP 14
Key Provisions: Lack of consistency between transparency under UCTD (comprehensibility) vs CCD (format/position); enforcement authorities struggle with guidance
Relevance: Demonstrates problems when transparency standards unclear; national authorities may develop narrow interpretations depriving consumers of protection

Name: Dark Patterns and EU Consumer Law (BEUC, multiple academic sources)
Key Provisions: Article 7 UCPD applies to hiding information/providing in unclear manner; Article 6 covers misleading presentation including vagueness
Relevance: Application of UCPD to digital practices that obscure material information; vague terms can constitute misleading omissions

Name: Schaub (2017) 'Mandatory Information Requirements in Consumer Law' ERPL
Key Provisions: Article 5 CRD requires trader specify contract duration, termination manner; functionality and interoperability for digital content; transparency requirements accompany information items
Relevance: Explains CRD information requirements for continuous performance contracts; failure triggers remedies under contract law

Name: EC Report on Modernisation Directive Implementation (2024)
Key Provisions: Commission assessment of Directive 2019/2161 transposition; identifies gaps and areas for improvement in digital consumer protection
Relevance: Official evaluation of enhanced consumer protection measures; signals future policy directions for closing gaps

Name: Regulation 2017/2394 (Consumer Protection Cooperation - CPC)
Key Provisions: Coordinates national authority enforcement of consumer protection laws; enables cross-border coordinated actions
Relevance: Procedural mechanism for enforcing substantive consumer protection rules including UCPD, UCTD, CRD across Member States

Name: Charter of Fundamental Rights Article 38
Key Provisions: EU policies shall ensure high level of consumer protection
Relevance: Constitutional foundation for consumer protection; informs interpretation of directives toward effective consumer safeguards
